page.title: 02WHAT! NO TRAINS IN OUNDLE!
page.content: Oundle had been served by a railway since 1845, when a branch line was opened from Blisworth to Peterborough. The town was fully served by passenger and freight trains for a century, with an upsurge in traffic during the 1939_45 war, when road transport was severely restricted. In 1948 the railways were nationalised, and the line serving Oundle came under the Eastern region of the new British Railways. The railways were in poor condition after the war, and this, coupled with the rise in private car ownership and road haulage, meant that railways declined in the 1950's. This line was closed as a result of the Beeching Report in 1963. Passenger traffic stopped in 1964, but Oundle station remained as a railhead for freight from Peterborough. This traffic ceased in 1972.
